title: 110_hr3597
content: The Act may be cited as the "Increasing Education Opportunities for Nurses and Nurse Faculty Act of 2007". The Congress acknowledges the crisis in the American healthcare system, with an estimated 44,000 to 98,000 deaths annually due to medical errors. The shortage of Registered Nurses (RNs) is a significant factor compromising patient safety, as low nurse staffing levels contribute to a quarter of hospital patient deaths and injuries. The nursing shortage is projected to worsen, with a predicted shortfall of over one million nurses by 2020. The nursing shortage is projected to worsen, with a predicted shortfall of over one million nurses by 2020. More registered nurses must be educated to meet the demanding needs of the future, especially as 78 million baby boomers age and require additional health care services. The constraints in nursing education programs have intensified over the last nine years. Enrollment and Graduations in Baccalaureate and Graduate Programs in Nursing, U.S. nursing schools turned away 42,866 qualified applicants in 2006 due to various constraints. Graduations increased by 18 percent from 2005 to 2006 in entry-level baccalaureate nursing programs, but this does not meet the demand. Congress provided Capitation Grants to nursing schools from 1971 to 1978 based on student enrollment. The Nurse Training Acts of 1971 and 1975 increased enrollments in nursing schools and helped address nursing shortages. A 2006 report by the National League for Nursing highlighted a growing number of unfilled nurse faculty positions across the country. SEC. 3. NURSING EDUCATION. Title VII of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to include additional capacity for R.N. students or graduate-level nursing students. The Secretary will award grants to institutions of higher education offering R.N. nursing programs to expand faculty and facilities for more students or accommodate advanced practice degrees for R.N.s and graduate-level nursing students. Each institution must determine the average number of students for the previous 4 academic years to apply for a grant. The Secretary awards grants to institutions of higher education with R.N. nursing programs to expand faculty and facilities. Institutions must determine the average number of students for the previous 4 academic years to apply for a grant. The grant amount is $3,000 multiplied by the number of matriculated nursing program students exceeding the average number. The Secretary awards grants to institutions of higher education for nursing programs. Grants are distributed among different degree programs based on specified percentages. The Secretary awards grants to institutions of higher education for expanding R.N. nursing programs at the baccalaureate and associate degree levels. If funds remain after grants are awarded for a specific category of nursing programs, equal amounts will be distributed. The Secretary will distribute remaining funds equally for grants to applicants in different categories of nursing programs, ensuring equitable geographic and institutional distribution. Funds provided cannot be used for new facility construction. Funds provided under this section can be used for repair or renovation of facilities. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out this section.
